Thank you for the lecture!  In 29:55, we found k (mod p), and the lecturer says that we therefore know k. How do we know k from k (mod p)?  In the previous example (24:15), with m (mod p), we know that m (mod p) = m because m < p. However, with k, we never explicitly restricted k to be less than p. Is that an assumption that was never mentioned, or am I missing something?  edit: I realize where I went wrong here. Instead of computing k^{-1}, we are computing k^{-1} (mod p), which can be done using k (mod p).

Hi  Felipe, Using the  part 2 of Lemma 4.2.4 (from the 4th chapter of the book in the reading section): we know : gcd(ka, kb) = k * gcd(a,b)  for all k > 0  is true :  hence using that we can prove gcd( m'1 , m'2 ) = k                                ... Since  gcd(m1*k , m2*k)  =  k * gcd(m1,m2)  and as m1 and m2 are relatively prime gcd(m1, m2) = 1  In case if you are searching for documents for proof  :  gcd(ka, kb) = k * gcd(a,b)  for all k > 0 :   https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/2448772/prove-gcdka-kb-k-cdot-gcda-b

@felipe1055  , yes as you pointed out there were many mistakes in my earlier proof, however I have edited my original comment to accommodate new proof which seems to be true, you can have a look and let me know your thoughts.
@srinivaskarthik1692  Hi, Srinivas! Yes, it seems that your proof is correct. Thank you very much! It was very helpful!
@felipe1055  thank you Felipe for the link to your proof , it was really helpful

Another way to see this - every number has a unique prime factorization. And every divisor can be formed by taking a product of permutation of prime factors. If gcd(m1',m2') > k, then it means that there exists a permutation of primes whose product > k. But there exists only one permutation because m1, m2, and p are prime numbers

If you are struggling with this material, which is actually fascinating and a joy to learn (the proof of Euler's Theorem is mindblowing, and the proof that RSA decryption works is pretty neat too), I recommend that you watch first a much gentler and clearer introduction, which is the following lecture in Christof Paar's excellent Introduction to Cryptography course:    Lecture 11"Number Theory for PKC: Euclidean Algorithm, Euler's Phi Function & Euler's Theorem" (https://youtu.be/fq6SXByItUI ), and maybe also the subsequent RSA lectures; also watch Lecture 2 first if your understanding of modular arithmetic is shaky, the explanation is crystal clear (https://youtu.be/W1SY6qKZrUk ). Then you will be primed (no pun) to easily follow the number theory proofs in this video, which Paar doesn't do.    Although watching so many videos  may seem like a lot of work, you will achieve confident understanding faster, and you will be a lot less likely to complain about this lecture, which is indeed quite dense. For this reason, I also recommend that you take notes during the lecture. This will allow you to easily follow the whole proof, rather than being restricted to the blackboard's portion that happens to be displayed at any given time. It is already hard enough when you have the whole proof in front of you, don't make it harder that it already is. Remember that these MIT students see all the boards during the lecture; they also have recitation, TAs, and each other, you have a lot less help. But the videos I mentioned will come to the rescue.   All things considered, the lecturer does a damn good job IMHO.

I see a lot of negative comments here! And initially I too supported all the comments, but it took me a while to understand that the problem is not with the lecturer, but its with the view. We do not have a view of all the blackboards at a time, and hence its hard for us to refer back and forth.  And the way out to this is, start taking notes of all the things he writes on the blackboard. It will appear tedious in the beginning and will take a little long to complete this lecture, but I am sure you will come back to thank me later! Worked for me,  and it will work for you as well. Have fun :)

It's not that he's a bad lecturer, this is just simply a problem with working memory and not having control over the view of the blackboards. For a complex subject such as this this will be an inevitable problem whoever the lecturer, there are just too many variables to keep them in your working memory. It is good to go into mathematics knowing that it can not be read like a novel. Thus it seems to me that it is equally important for a math student to draw their knowledge from books as for other subjects such as philosophy. If one does this and is intelligent, I think it should be possible to grasp mathematics that uses concepts one is not even familiar with and tackle these growing number of subfields in a creative way as opposed to the boring and repetitive ''banging it into your head'' maths that you see in high school. Reading allows you to keep track of all elements and tackle them at your own pace instead of expecting yourself to comprehend all elements at first sight. Well then it just sucks that math books are fucking expensive beyond reason while MIT lectures are available right here on the internet.

He uses equals and congruent interchangeably at times; yet when he defined congruence he defined it in terms of a relationship involving divisibility and differences (so was he really defining congruence or two equivalent ideas [modulo and divisibility] while using congruence?) - I think the major flaw of this lecture is the failure to explain the subtleties involved in the definitions as well as supply some measure of intuition. Plus, it was very disorganized. It took me more than 2 hours to watch this lecture, pausing and rewinding, and towards the end I barely understood a bulk of it.
